1.learning_goal: Foundations of AI: In this unit, students will build a practical, non-sci-fi understanding of what AI is, how it evolved from rule-based to data-driven systems, distinguish symbolic/statistical and narrow/general AI, correctly use terms like ML, DL, and LLMs, and apply these concepts to classify real-world examples and everyday applications.

chapters.title: Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
chapters.learning_goals: Build a practical, non-sci‑fi understanding of what AI is, how it differs from traditional software, and how it developed from rule-based systems to data-driven approaches, while practicing classification of real-world examples and mapping key milestones on an AI timeline.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What Is Artificial Intelligence?
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define Artificial Intelligence in practical, non-sci-fi terms; Identify what makes a system “intelligent” in practice; Distinguish AI systems from traditional software

lessons.title: A Short History of AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe how early AI systems were built; Explain why early AI relied on rules and logic; Identify what changed when data became central

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Spot the AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify whether real-world examples are AI, traditional software, or not software at all, and justify the classification. Output: A completed worksheet where each example is labeled and explained as AI, non-AI software, or non-software.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: AI Timeline and Turning Points
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reconstruct a simplified timeline of AI history and connect each era to its core idea (rules vs data). Output: A filled-in timeline chart with key AI milestones, their characteristics, and short explanations of what changed at each turning point.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Foundations of Rule-Based and Data-Driven AI
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will distinguish between rule-based (symbolic) and data-driven (statistical) AI by defining each approach, exploring their strengths and limitations, and practicing both through hands-on activities. They will design a simple rule engine, build a basic data-driven recommendation process, and use Q&A sessions to clarify concepts and connect them to real-world applications.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Rule-Based AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define rule-based (symbolic) AI; Explain how rules are written and applied; Identify strengths and limitations of rule-based systems

lessons.title: Data-Driven AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define data-driven (statistical) AI; Explain how data replaces explicit rules; Describe why data-driven systems scale better

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Coffee Shop Rule Engine
lessons.learning_outcomes: Design and test a small set of explicit IF–THEN rules to simulate how a barista decides drink prices and discounts. Output: A written or pseudo-coded rule set that, given an order description, determines the correct price and discount.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie Recommendation Cards
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build a simple “data-driven” recommendation process using example user data instead of explicit rules. Output: A filled-out set of cards or a table that shows how different user viewing histories lead to different recommended movies based on patterns in the data.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Foundations of Modern AI
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to distinguish symbolic vs. statistical AI and narrow vs. general AI, apply these distinctions to real-world examples, and critically evaluate common misconceptions about current AI capabilities.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Symbolic vs Statistical AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Clearly distinguish symbolic AI from statistical AI; Compare how each approach handles complexity; Identify which approach powers most modern AI systems

lessons.title: Narrow AI vs General AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define Narrow AI using real-world examples; Define General AI conceptually and explain why it does not exist today; Correct common misconceptions about AI capabilities

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Symbolic vs Statistical Sorting
lessons.learning_outcomes: Correctly classify example AI systems as symbolic or statistical and explain how each handles complexity in that context. Output: A comparison table where each example system is labeled symbolic/statistical with one-sentence reasoning.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Narrow vs General AI Scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish narrow AI from hypothetical general AI and debunk common myths using concrete scenarios. Output: A completed scenario sheet where each scenario is tagged as “narrow AI”, “imagined general AI”, or “not AI”, with brief justifications.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Foundations of Modern AI
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn to distinguish ML, DL, and LLMs, connect them to statistical AI, and use accurate terminology to describe real-world AI systems. They will also identify everyday AI applications across industries, analyze the data they rely on, and explain how data quality and bias shape system behavior.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: ML, DL, and LLMs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and LLMs; Explain how these approaches relate to statistical AI; Use correct terminology when describing modern systems

lessons.title: AI in the Real World
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify real-world applications of AI across industries; Describe what type of data these systems rely on; Explain why AI behavior depends on data quality

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: ML, DL, LLM Match-Up
lessons.learning_outcomes: Accurately match real-world systems to ML, DL, or LLM categories and describe the data they use. Output: A completed matching and short-answer sheet mapping example applications to ML/DL/LLM with one-sentence explanations.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: AI in Everyday Life Map
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify AI use-cases across multiple industries and explain how data quality shapes their behavior. Output: A simple “AI in my world” map listing at least 6 applications, the data they rely on, and a note on what happens if that data is biased or low quality.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

2.learning_goal: Tabular Data Foundations: In this unit, students will learn to load real datasets into Pandas DataFrames, inspect and understand their structure, select and filter rows and columns, create grouped summaries and derived columns, and apply basic data quality checks while clearly explaining their data transformation logic.

chapters.title: Working with Real-World Tabular Data
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn how to represent tabular data with Pandas Series and DataFrames, load real CSV files, and inspect their structure and contents. They will practice identifying basic data issues immediately after loading and gain confidence by building small, hands-on examples and discussing questions in live sessions.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: DataFrames and Series
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define DataFrame and Series using tabular data examples; Explain how rows and columns map to DataFrame structure; Navigate and inspect basic DataFrame components

lessons.title: Loading Real Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load CSV data into a Pandas DataFrame; Verify that data loaded correctly using inspection methods; Identify basic issues immediately after loading data

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe orders table
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice creating Series and DataFrames from small tabular cafe order data and inspecting rows, columns, and basic structure. Output: A script that builds a tiny cafe orders DataFrame and prints its head, shape, columns, and a few Series slices.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie ratings CSV loader
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load a CSV of fictional movie ratings into a DataFrame, inspect it with Pandas methods, and spot immediate loading issues (missing values, wrong types, odd values). Output: A script that reads a movie_ratings.csv file, prints key inspection summaries, and highlights any obvious data problems after loading.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Reading and Filtering DataFrames
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to carefully inspect tabular datasets, identify basic data issues, and intentionally select and filter columns and rows. Practice applying these skills to answer real questions about playlists and customer orders, while clearly explaining your filtering logic in plain language.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Reading Data Carefully
lessons.learning_outcomes: Inspect datasets to understand structure and content; Identify potential data issues by scanning rows and columns; Formulate simple questions about what the data represents

lessons.title: Selecting and Filtering
lessons.learning_outcomes: Select specific columns from a DataFrame intentionally; Filter rows using logical conditions; Explain filtering logic clearly in plain language

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music app playlist explorer
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use column selection and row filtering on a playlist DataFrame to answer questions about songs, durations, and artists, and explain the filtering logic in plain language. Output: A script that loads a playlist DataFrame and prints several filtered views (e.g., long songs, songs by an artist, specific columns only).

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Customer orders filter
lessons.learning_outcomes: Carefully inspect an e-commerce orders dataset, identify structural patterns and potential issues, then select and filter rows to answer simple business questions. Output: A script that reads an orders CSV and prints answers to questions like “orders over $100”, “orders from a given country”, and “selected key columns”.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Grouping and Enriching Data with Pandas
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to group data by key categories, compute and interpret basic aggregations, and create useful derived columns in Pandas. By the end of this chapter, you’ll be able to summarize real-world datasets (like cafe sales and fitness tracking logs) and enhance them with calculated metrics to support better analysis.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Grouping Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Group data by categorical features using Pandas; Apply basic aggregations such as mean and count; Interpret grouped results in terms of real-world meaning

lessons.title: Derived Columns
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create new columns derived from existing data; Explain why derived columns can make data more useful; Verify correctness of newly created columns

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe sales summary
lessons.learning_outcomes: Group cafe transaction data by product and by day, compute basic aggregations (count, mean price, total revenue), and interpret what the grouped results say about sales patterns. Output: A script that prints grouped tables summarizing number of items sold and revenue per product and per day.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fitness tracker metrics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create derived columns (e.g., pace, calories_estimate, distance_km) from raw fitness tracking data and verify their correctness with spot checks and reasoning. Output: A script that reads a workout DataFrame, adds several calculated columns, and prints before/after views to confirm the new metrics.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Thinking in Tables and Ensuring Data Quality
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn to reason confidently about how common tabular operations transform rows and columns, and to apply essential data quality checks before analysis. They will practice predicting table changes, implementing a basic data quality checklist, and articulating why these steps are critical for reliable data work.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Thinking in Tables
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reason about data transformations in terms of rows and columns; Predict how operations will change a dataset’s structure; Develop confidence manipulating tabular data logically

lessons.title: Data Quality Checks
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand different data quality checks and why they are important; Perform basic checks to assess data quality; Explain why quality checks should happen before analysis

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Thinking in tables scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: Strengthen the ability to mentally model how tabular operations (select, filter, group, derive columns) change rows and columns using written scenarios and table-based questions. Output: A completed written exercise where the learner predicts resulting tables, matches operations to outcomes, and explains table transformations.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Data quality checklist
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply basic data quality checks (missing values, duplicates, out-of-range values, type issues) to a sample dataset and explain why each check matters before analysis. Output: A script that runs a small suite of quality checks on a DataFrame and prints a concise “data quality report” summary.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

3.learning_goal: Foundations of EDA: In this unit, students will clean and type-correct real datasets, detect and interpret outliers, apply purposeful filtering and grouping, and use basic plots to conduct exploratory data analysis that reveals patterns, anomalies, and meaningful questions without over-interpreting results.

chapters.title: Preparing Data Types and Outliers for Analysis
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to correctly set and fix data types, detect and interpret outliers using basic numerical and visual methods, and decide when to investigate, keep, or treat anomalies as data issues in real-world datasets.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Fixing Data Types
lessons.learning_outcomes: Detect columns with incorrect data types; Convert data types to enable proper analysis; Explain why correct data types are essential

lessons.title: Detecting and Understanding Outliers
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify outliers using simple numerical and visual methods; Distinguish between meaningful outliers and problematic outliers; Explain why outliers should be investigated, not automatically removed

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe sales data types
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice detecting and correcting incorrect data types in a small cafe sales dataset and explain why each change is needed. Output: A cleaned DataFrame where dates, numeric prices, and quantities have correct data types ready for analysis.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Ride-sharing outlier hunt
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify, visualize, and interpret outliers in a ride-sharing trips dataset, distinguishing meaningful anomalies from data errors. Output: A short report (notebook cells or markdown) with plots and notes labeling which outliers to investigate, keep, or treat as data issues.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Purposeful Filtering and Grouping
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to filter and group datasets with clear intent, explain and validate your choices, and interpret aggregated results to uncover meaningful patterns and business insights.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Filtering with Purpose
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply filters based on meaningful conditions; Explain why specific filters are applied; Validate that filtering produced expected results

lessons.title: Grouping for Insight
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use grouping to compare categories in data; Interpret aggregated values meaningfully; Identify patterns revealed through grouping

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie ratings filtering
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply purposeful filters to a movie ratings dataset, justify each filter, and verify that the filtered subset matches expectations. Output: A filtered DataFrame of movies that meet clear criteria (e.g., minimum rating count and average rating) plus simple checks confirming the filters worked.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Online store grouping insights
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use grouping and aggregation on an online store orders dataset to compare categories and extract interpretable business insights. Output: Grouped summary tables (e.g., revenue by category, average order value by region) with brief written interpretations of the main patterns.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Exploring Data Through First Plots
chapters.learning_goals: Learn what exploratory data analysis (EDA) is, why it matters before modeling or decisions, and how it differs from final conclusions. Practice creating and interpreting basic matplotlib plots to uncover trends and patterns in real data.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What EDA Really Means
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define exploratory data analysis in clear, practical terms; Explain the goals of EDA before modeling or decisions; Distinguish EDA from final conclusions

lessons.title: First Plots for Insight
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create basic plots using matplotlib; Choose plot types appropriate to specific questions; Interpret plots to describe trends and patterns

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: EDA concepts check
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reinforce understanding of what EDA is, its goals, and how it differs from final conclusions using matching, classification, and short-answer prompts. Output: A completed worksheet or notebook with answered questions categorizing statements as EDA vs. final conclusions and explaining EDA goals.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music app first plots
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create and interpret basic matplotlib plots for a music streaming dataset, choosing appropriate chart types for different exploratory questions. Output: A set of plots (histogram, bar chart, line plot, or scatter plot) with brief text describing the main trends and patterns observed.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Exploring Patterns in Data
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn to distinguish data types, recognize patterns and anomalies, and classify questions as univariate or relationship-based. They will practice selecting appropriate summaries and visualizations, and communicating exploratory findings clearly without over-interpreting.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Patterns and Anomalies
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify patterns emerging from data exploration; Detect anomalies and unusual values; Explain findings clearly without over-interpreting

lessons.title: Data Types & “What am I analyzing?”
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish numerical vs categorical variables; Identify whether a question is univariate or relationship-based; Understand that choosing appropriate summary statistics and visualizations is based on data type and know the main techniques according to data type

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Patterns and question types
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice recognizing patterns vs anomalies and classifying questions as univariate or relationship-based, matching each to suitable summaries and visuals. Output: A completed exercise where each example variable and question is labeled (numerical/categorical, univariate/relationship) with an appropriate summary and plot type selected.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Customer churn pattern scanner
lessons.learning_outcomes: Analyze a customer churn-style dataset to detect key patterns and anomalies while clearly stating what can and cannot be concluded from the data. Output: A concise exploratory summary with tables and simple visuals highlighting main patterns and flagged anomalies, plus short explanations that avoid over-interpretation.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

4.learning_goal: Foundations of Data Relationships: In this unit, students will develop intuitive understanding of variability, randomness, and probability; identify and interpret relationships between two or more variables (including different types of correlation); and practice distinguishing noise from signal and correlation from causation using realistic data scenarios.

chapters.title: Understanding Variability and Randomness
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will build an intuitive understanding of variability, standard deviation, randomness, and noise in real-world data. They will practice distinguishing signal from noise and explaining why repeated measurements can differ, using concrete stories and visual examples.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Variability & Standard Deviation (Intuition)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain variability as how spread out values are; Interpret standard deviation at an intuitive level; Compare two datasets and infer which has more variability

lessons.title: Randomness, Noise & Why patterns can be misleading
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define randomness and noise in real datasets; Recognize when a pattern may be caused by noise rather than signal; Explain why repeated measurements or samples may lead to different results

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Weather variability story
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice intuitively judging which of several fictional towns has higher variability and standard deviation in daily temperatures. Output: A completed worksheet/story where each town is labeled as “more/less variable” with short written explanations.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Noise vs signal in café sales
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice deciding whether apparent patterns in a café’s daily customer counts are likely noise or meaningful signal, and explain why repeated measurements differ. Output: A set of annotated mini-charts and short answers classifying each pattern as “likely noise” or “likely signal” with reasoning.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Bivariate Relationships and Correlation
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn to recognize when questions require bivariate analysis, select suitable visualizations for different pairs of variable types, and interpret how two variables move together. They will also learn to distinguish between Pearson and Spearman correlation at a high level and decide which is more appropriate in different real-world scenarios.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Bivariate Thinking - Relationships between two variables
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify when a question requires bivariate analysis; Choose an appropriate visualization for different variable type combinations; Describe what it means for two variables to move together

lessons.title: Correlation - Pearson vs Spearman (High level)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define correlation and interpret positive vs negative correlation; Differentiate Pearson (linear) vs Spearman (rank or monotonic) at a high level; Explain when Spearman may be more appropriate than Pearson

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Matching questions to visualizations
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice identifying when a question needs bivariate analysis and matching it to an appropriate visualization for different variable type combinations. Output: A completed matching table where each real-world question is paired with a visualization choice (scatterplot, bar chart, boxplot, etc.) and a brief justification.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Correlation stories – Pearson vs Spearman
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice interpreting positive and negative correlations from short scenarios and deciding whether Pearson or Spearman correlation is more appropriate. Output: A set of scenario answers indicating correlation direction/strength and whether Pearson or Spearman fits best, with one-sentence explanations.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Thinking Beyond Correlation
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to distinguish correlation from causation, recognize confounders and reverse causality, and apply multivariate thinking to see how relationships change when additional variables are considered. Practice critiquing causal claims in real-world-style examples and revising interpretations when controlling for other factors, building intuition for better data and modeling decisions.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Correlation ≠ Causation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why correlation does not imply causation; Identify common pitfalls such as confounders and reverse causality; Propose ways to reduce wrong conclusions by considering other variables and domain reasoning

lessons.title: Multivariate Intuition - When relationships change
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why adding a third variable can change an observed relationship; Describe controlling for another variable conceptually; Understand how multivariate thinking connects to feature selection and ML modeling decisions at a high level

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Correlation vs causation detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice spotting confounders, reverse causality, and weak causal claims in short news-style summaries and proposing safer interpretations. Output: A marked-up list of claims labeled as “correlation only,” “possible causation,” or “misleading,” each with a brief note about confounders or alternative explanations.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Multivariate twists in relationships
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice reasoning through how adding a third variable can change observed relationships and what it means to “control for” another variable conceptually. Output: A set of small case analyses where initial two-variable conclusions are revised after introducing a third variable, with written before/after interpretations.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Understanding Uncertainty and Samples
chapters.learning_goals: Students will learn to describe probability as a way of expressing uncertainty, interpret everyday probability statements, and distinguish between samples and populations. They will also practice recognizing why results vary across samples and why small or biased samples can lead to misleading conclusions.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Probability as Uncertainty (High level)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain probability as a way to describe uncertainty; Interpret probability statements in everyday terms; Connect probability to variability and why results are not exact

lessons.title: Samples vs Population - Why results vary
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish population vs sample intuitively; Explain why different samples give different results; Describe why we should be cautious about trusting patterns from small samples

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Everyday probability scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice translating informal uncertainty phrases (like “unlikely,” “almost certain”) into rough probability ranges and connecting them to real-life variability. Output: A completed set of scenario responses where each everyday statement is assigned an approximate probability and a short explanation of the uncertainty involved.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Samples vs population – survey puzzles
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice distinguishing samples from populations using mini-survey stories and explaining why small or biased samples can give misleading patterns. Output: A worksheet of survey vignettes labeled with “population,” “sample,” and “risk of error,” plus short notes on why different samples might yield different results.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges
